commit_message:
Avoid tox-install.sh

Instead of using tox-install.sh, we can install nova now directly
from pypi - or use the current branch in CI system using tox-siblings.

Update tox.ini for this change. Use new location for constraints file.

Add nova to requirements file.

Update sphinx requirements to pass requirements check.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/663234
Change-Id: Ic6637a9668929100c9dbb95933acc11117f0980b

commit_message:
Avoid tox-install.sh

Instead of using tox-install.sh, we can install nova now directly
from pypi - or use the current branch in CI system using tox-siblings.

Update tox.ini for this change. Use new location for constraints file.

Add nova to requirements file.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/663234
Change-Id: I3073d24c5c0827760dcc412e4c380d062253342e

commit_message:
Remove deprecated PBR option 'warnerrors'

PBR option 'warnerrors' has been deprecated and replaced by
sphinx-build option "sphinx-build -W ..." in tox.ini,
as recommended by OpenStack Project Testing Interface:

  https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html#documentation

Change-Id: Ib74d40fad1ff368d774990f3df17b64990f6b32a
Story: 2004693

[{'account_id': 30380, 'date': '2019-05-07 03:31:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-05-07 03:31:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-05-07 05:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
openstack port create support --extra-dhcp-option

neutron create-port API  has extra_dhcp_opts parameter, this parameter
can set port with special extra dhcp options.

Change-Id: I199f17e95c509a33f809ac85c65f685a37acd198

commit_message:
Update build profiles for Placement split

The Placement API is now a separate project, but anyone
building Nova is likely to want it. This change ensures
that it is built alongside Nova.

Change-Id: I05433f5bb2313e2adff39850a970d4430340c852
(cherry picked from commit d4e89eb932d660b4e610460b3ec9792a3e08091c)

commit_message:
Update build profiles for Placement split

The Placement API is now a separate project, but anyone
building Nova is likely to want it. This change ensures
that it is built alongside Nova.

Change-Id: I05433f5bb2313e2adff39850a970d4430340c852
(cherry picked from commit d4e89eb932d660b4e610460b3ec9792a3e08091c)

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-34447 : FAILURE in 1h 00m 23s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 14:02:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for doing this. I noticed last week that the link in the comment in libvirt/utils.py was busted, but wasn't sure what should be done about it.

One question, though: do you know *when* this was changed? Because I'm looking at my bionic devstack victim and it still has /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml.

I would hate to have to say ".../usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml for libvirt prior to version X.Y.Z; /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map/* thereafter..." everywhere, but unfortunately that may be necessary :('}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-07-29 14:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
doc: correct the information of 'cpu_map'

libvirt has split the CPU feature flags file 'cpu_map.xml' into
a bunch of flag files for each CPU model, which are stored under
directory 'src/cpu_map/'.

Update this change accordingly.

Change-Id: Id45587adb6ecd8e0bdef344c90979eaea61e61b8

commit_message:
Fix log directory permissions for functional job

After [0] devstack no longer changes the ownership of the whole
/opt/stack tree to the stack user unconditionally. So we need to create
/opt/stack/logs with the correct owner directly.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/203698

Change-Id: I4597c83bfce6267ef93bb8f7b0de62fa3ac94db4
Closes-Bug: 1838811

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-10-26 07:48:31.000000000', 'message': 'Enable DeprecationWarning in test environments

Many deprecations are triggered early (on imports, for example).
To make sure all DeprecationWarning messages are emitted we enable
them via the PYTHONWARNINGS environment variable.

Change-Id: I3890dadba51bd1a112ac24bfb3a1e15afe96d3e1
'}]
commit_message:
Enable DeprecationWarning in test environments

Many deprecations are triggered early (on imports, for example).
To make sure all DeprecationWarning messages are emitted we enable
them via the PYTHONWARNINGS environment variable.

Change-Id: I3890dadba51bd1a112ac24bfb3a1e15afe96d3e1

commit_message:
Add CloudRegion helper method for arbitrary endpoints

Sometimes you are faced with dealing with a non-standard service and
you don't want to type

   c.session.auth.get_endpoint(
      c.session, service_type='example-service-type',
      region_name=c.config.region_name, interface=c.config.interface))

Add a helper method so you don't have to.

Change-Id: I50d179abc528a884bae4b4af72936b634b26e93b

subject: Remove unnecessary option from group_vars/all.yml
messages: [{'account_id': 19779, 'date': '2019-08-02 02:07:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-08-02 06:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-03 17:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-02 02:07:59.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unnecessary option from group_vars/all.yml

We often specific the project name after "{{ node_config_directory }}",
for example,
``{{ node_config_directory }}/cinder-api/:{{ container_config_directory }}/:ro``.
As the  "{{ project }}" option is not configured, This line was
generated with:
``/etc/kolla//cinder-api/:...``
There would be double slash exists. It's OK, but confusing.

Change-Id: I82e6a91b2c541e38cf8e97896842149b31244688
Closes-Bug: #1838259
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unnecessary option from group_vars/all.yml

We often specific the project name after "{{ node_config_directory }}",
for example,
``{{ node_config_directory }}/cinder-api/:{{ container_config_directory }}/:ro``.
As the  "{{ project }}" option is not configured, This line was
generated with:
``/etc/kolla//cinder-api/:...``
There would be double slash exists. It's OK, but confusing.

Change-Id: I82e6a91b2c541e38cf8e97896842149b31244688
Closes-Bug: #1838259

commit_message:
Enable service token in nova and cinder

This patch enables service token feature in nova and cinder, which
can be used to avoid problems in inter-component request caused by
token expiration for long running tasks.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666467/
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666471/
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666746/
Change-Id: Ia9cab3080a6e0ef7433fa0be19b98f8e63bae587

subject: Use placement for unified resource management
messages:
[{'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2018-07-30 07:28:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-08-01 02:47:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Cool! Since this is a big patch, I will allocate another time to look into the details.'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2018-08-01 03:30:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Cool! Since this is a big patch, I will allocate another time to
 > look into the details.

Thanks @hongbin

1. zun-compute and nova-compute are deployed in the same machine
2. resources which recorded in placement database are reported by nova-compute 
3. We can get the valid host by placement api
4. zun-compute and nova-compute recorded in compute_node have different UUIDs. But the hostname of them are the same. We can pretend to the valid hosts in zun-compute.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-08-03 02:55:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

Just doing an initial pass. Several comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-08-03 03:47:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(11 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-07 15:09:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-07 15:49:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-07 20:29:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-07 21:53:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-07 23:22:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-15 09:55:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Unless you have a specific need to duplicate nova's functionality, I would advise against duplicating the report client directly. Its behavior is not ideal and its structure evolved organically over time as nova's requirements changed.

Since you're in a new environment it would probably better to implement something that does the same thing, but using techniques more directly aligned with both Zun's needs and the more contemporary ways of using placement."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-16 00:02:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Unless you have a specific need to duplicate nova's functionality,
 > I would advise against duplicating the report client directly. Its
 > behavior is not ideal and its structure evolved organically over
 > time as nova's requirements changed.
 > 
 > Since you're in a new environment it would probably better to
 > implement something that does the same thing, but using techniques
 > more directly aligned with both Zun's needs and the more
 > contemporary ways of using placement.

Chris,

I wanted to pick the fastest path to bootstrap the code. Copying nova's code seems to be the easiest approach for us to do that. An alternative approach is to write the placement client code from scratch, which is a much heavier approach.

If there is an alternative way that allows us to have a fast bootstrap of the codebase, please advice. Also, I would like to know why the existing nova code is not ideal. Appreciate if you can share more details about that."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-16 07:55:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> I wanted to pick the fastest path to bootstrap the code. Copying
 > nova's code seems to be the easiest approach for us to do that. An
 > alternative approach is to write the placement client code from
 > scratch, which is a much heavier approach.

Yes, I suppose that makes sense. I hope you'll have the time to refactor it and adapt it more cleanly to zun's needs, over time.

 > If there is an alternative way that allows us to have a fast
 > bootstrap of the codebase, please advice. Also, I would like to
 > know why the existing nova code is not ideal. Appreciate if you can
 > share more details about that.

You could also look at how neutron is using placement. They've taken a different approach, in part because they're reporting patterns are different.

If you continue to use the nova report client, some things that we wish we had done differently while integrating placement include:

* The @safe_connect decorator does not really work as designed and ends up getting in the way of calling code handling errors effectively. We're working to remove it.
* Some methods which retrieve data are inconsistent about being functional (returning a new data structure) or modifying a data structure that is passed to the method, or carried on the object. It would be helpful if they were only functional.
* Error handling (unexpected HTTP response from server) and missing data handling (not getting the expected results in a valid response) is sometimes mixed together, meaning you can't know which is which when a method returns a null response. Was it an error? Was there not data? We don't know!
* If you're not using nested resource providers, the ProviderTree object is overkill.

That's just a few of the issues. It is getting better as we have the opportunity to clean things up.

The reason I bring this is up is that historically OpenStack projects have duplicated the architecture and techniques present in nova, not realizing that they are a) really rather old and out of date, b) not particularly good choices in the first place, c) where they are good choices, good only for the specific multi-node environment in which nova is operating."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-20 21:03:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> > I wanted to pick the fastest path to bootstrap the code. Copying
 > > nova's code seems to be the easiest approach for us to do that.
 > An
 > > alternative approach is to write the placement client code from
 > > scratch, which is a much heavier approach.
 > 
 > Yes, I suppose that makes sense. I hope you'll have the time to
 > refactor it and adapt it more cleanly to zun's needs, over time.
 > 
 > > If there is an alternative way that allows us to have a fast
 > > bootstrap of the codebase, please advice. Also, I would like to
 > > know why the existing nova code is not ideal. Appreciate if you
 > can
 > > share more details about that.
 > 
 > You could also look at how neutron is using placement. They've
 > taken a different approach, in part because they're reporting
 > patterns are different.
 > 
 > If you continue to use the nova report client, some things that we
 > wish we had done differently while integrating placement include:
 > 
 > * The @safe_connect decorator does not really work as designed and
 > ends up getting in the way of calling code handling errors
 > effectively. We're working to remove it.
 > * Some methods which retrieve data are inconsistent about being
 > functional (returning a new data structure) or modifying a data
 > structure that is passed to the method, or carried on the object.
 > It would be helpful if they were only functional.
 > * Error handling (unexpected HTTP response from server) and missing
 > data handling (not getting the expected results in a valid
 > response) is sometimes mixed together, meaning you can't know which
 > is which when a method returns a null response. Was it an error?
 > Was there not data? We don't know!
 > * If you're not using nested resource providers, the ProviderTree
 > object is overkill.

Thanks for sharing these details. One thing I am sure is that Zun plans to use nested resource provider. Right now, Zun supports SRIOV that needs to be modeled by nested resource provider. Also, we are working on fully supporting NUMA topology that needs to use nested resource provider as well. Therefore, Zun would like to use the ProviderTree code.

I did a quick check on the nova client code with neutron client code. The API looks similar, except that nova uses ProviderTree and neutron does not. In term of the report pattern, my opinion is that nova pattern would be more aligned with what Zun needs, because Zun also has a compute node that needs to report compute host resource to placement.

As you suggested, nova code might not be perfect or even outdated. I am aware of that. I wished to use nova code as a fast bootstrap of the codebase, and evolves as needed. I will avoid copying the @safe_connect decorator in the first place since it is not ideal as you pointed out. For your second and third points, I will check if I can fix it at the beginning or leave it as future work.

However, I do have the same concern as you as the duplication of the code. The amount of duplicated code do introduce a burden for Zun team to maintaining the code. Eventually, I wish we can consolidate the common code into a library that both Zun and Nova consumes, probably similar as what neutron-lib did: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/placement/client.py .

 > 
 > That's just a few of the issues. It is getting better as we have
 > the opportunity to clean things up.
 > 
 > The reason I bring this is up is that historically OpenStack
 > projects have duplicated the architecture and techniques present in
 > nova, not realizing that they are a) really rather old and out of
 > date, b) not particularly good choices in the first place, c) where
 > they are good choices, good only for the specific multi-node
 > environment in which nova is operating."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-20 21:59:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-20 23:21:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-21 15:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-21 21:56:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-21 22:36:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-21 23:42:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-26 15:42:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

+100 what Chris said. Please believe me when I tell you that you will regret copying SchedulerReportClient wholesale. At the very least you should copy in one piece at a time as you find yourself needing it. But even then you're duplicating and assuming technical debt from nova as well as dragging in nova-specific logic that doesn't (can't possibly) make sense outside of nova.

I feel strongly enough about this to leave a -1. But then I'll go away, as will my vote when you respin (which you have to do anyway to fix tests)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-26 18:46:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> I wanted to pick the fastest path to bootstrap the code. Copying nova's code seems to be the easiest approach for us to do that. An alternative approach is to write the placement client code from scratch, which is a much heavier approach.

Watcher did it pretty easily to get started:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661245/"}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-27 00:44:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> +100 what Chris said. Please believe me when I tell you that you
 > will regret copying SchedulerReportClient wholesale. At the very
 > least you should copy in one piece at a time as you find yourself
 > needing it. But even then you're duplicating and assuming technical
 > debt from nova as well as dragging in nova-specific logic that
 > doesn't (can't possibly) make sense outside of nova.

Eric,

Appreciate your remark. I heard opinions against copying nova code from several members of nova team. The rationales are:

* There are technical debts
* Nova-specific logic doesn't make sense outside of nova

I would like to hear more details about that. What are the specific technical debts? What are the nova-specific logic that won't make sense for Zun? I will evaluate if I have the details.

 > 
 > I feel strongly enough about this to leave a -1. But then I'll go
 > away, as will my vote when you respin (which you have to do anyway
 > to fix tests)."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-27 00:56:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> > I wanted to pick the fastest path to bootstrap the code. Copying
 > nova's code seems to be the easiest approach for us to do that. An
 > alternative approach is to write the placement client code from
 > scratch, which is a much heavier approach.
 > 
 > Watcher did it pretty easily to get started:
 > 
 > https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661245/

Right, there is another example as well: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/placement/client.py . I really don't know how to make sure of those code, or have resource/knowledge to write similar code like those from scratch. Nova code is used by nova-compute to report compute host resource to placement. This is exactly what Zun's need because Zun also has a compute agent which also needs to report compute host resource. Copying nova code is the fastest path to bootstrap the codebase in my opinion."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-27 16:54:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-27 20:52:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-27 23:28:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-28 16:56:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-28 20:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-28 21:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-28 23:43:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-29 02:53:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-07-29 04:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2019-08-02 02:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review+2

Great!'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-08-03 15:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

When editing external bridge configuration and running a reconfigure

Change-Id: Iee39cf00b743ab0776354749c6e162814b5584d8

commit_message:
openvswitch: always run handler to to ensure OVS bridges are up

When editing external bridge configuration and running a reconfigure
on openvswitch, handler "Ensuring OVS bridge is properly setup"
needs to run, but doesn't.

This moves the task from handlers to own file and always includes it
after running the handlers.

Change-Id: Iee39cf00b743ab0776354749c6e162814b5584d8
Closes-Bug: #1794504
(cherry picked from commit 8736817a989213df0f40a72f7e7163d9792aee43)

commit_message:
Update build profiles for Placement split

The Placement API is now a separate project, but anyone
building Nova is likely to want it. This change ensures
that it is built alongside Nova.

Change-Id: I05433f5bb2313e2adff39850a970d4430340c852
(cherry picked from commit d4e89eb932d660b4e610460b3ec9792a3e08091c)

subject: CI: clean up requirements installation
messages: [{'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-26 12:13:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2019-07-26 12:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30381, 'date': '2019-07-29 01:46:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-03 15:44:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-26 12:13:30.000000000', 'message': "CI: clean up requirements installation

We install kolla-ansible requirements in Zuul's Ansible playbooks.
This patch cleans up the installation in scripts so that they are
only concerned with auxiliary requirements:
- ansible (since we do not track it in requirements)
- ara (for log summaries)
- openstack clients (for first init and tests after deployment)

Additionally this patch installs openstack clients in a separate
virtualenv.
Note that all kolla-ansible requirements, ansible and ara are still
installed system-wide.

Change-Id: Iac04082ad39a9d823c515ba11c5db9af50ed225f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 8a543098d68a4b945e62ce5c92ece0f5d73946bc)
"}]
commit_message:
CI: clean up requirements installation

We install kolla-ansible requirements in Zuul's Ansible playbooks.
This patch cleans up the installation in scripts so that they are
only concerned with auxiliary requirements:
- ansible (since we do not track it in requirements)
- ara (for log summaries)
- openstack clients (for first init and tests after deployment)

Additionally this patch installs openstack clients in a separate
virtualenv.
Note that all kolla-ansible requirements, ansible and ara are still
installed system-wide.

Change-Id: Iac04082ad39a9d823c515ba11c5db9af50ed225f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 8a543098d68a4b945e62ce5c92ece0f5d73946bc)

commit_message:
Add CI job for ironic

Adds four new CI jobs for testing centos/ubuntu binary/source deploys
with ironic enabled. These are run only when there are changes to the
ironic role.

Performs some simple testing by creating a node using the fake-hardware
hardware type and creating a server.

Change-Id: Ie669e57ce2af53257b4ca05f45193cb73f48827a
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/664011
(cherry picked from commit 845040ad3f2a477f5ab823391390e84355dd140e)

commit_message:
Fix handling of docker restart policy

Docker has no restart policy named 'never'. It has 'no'.
This has bitten us already (see [1]) and might bite us again whenever
we want to change the restart policy to 'no'.

This patch makes our docker integration honor all valid restart policies
and only valid restart policies.
All relevant docker restart policy usages are patched as well.

I added some FIXMEs around which are relevant to kolla-ansible docker
integration. They are not fixed in here to not alter behavior.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/667363

Change-Id: I1c9764fb9bbda08a71186091aced67433ad4e3d6
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

This repo uses storyboard since some time and not anymore launchpad:

Update the openstackdocstheme options so that the "Report a bug" link
points to storyboard and not to launchpad.

Change-Id: I5f42dac1987e0f90860beb12fc842e77cd627820

commit_message:
CI: fix checks for upgrade and multinode jobs

Multinode jobs did not run sanity checks for all the hosts,
only primary. Now they check all.

Additionally upgrades are now checked using the proper
(pre-upgrade) scripts (not that it matters too much as they
are the same atm) and both checks are done, not only failures,
but also config.

Change-Id: I10552e256edbddd5b1f8a8a7f8805262e72ce8d8
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2019-08-03 15:27:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix docstring and avoid such errors

Docs in octavia where failing with:
Docstring of octavia.api.drivers.amphora_driver.v1.driver.AmphoraProviderDriver.create_vip_port:

The broken docstring is in octavia_lib/api/drivers/provider_base.py. Fix

and require the package.

commit_message:
Fix docstring and avoid such errors

Docs in octavia where failing with:
Docstring of octavia.api.drivers.amphora_driver.v1.driver.AmphoraProviderDriver.create_vip_port:
10:Unexpected indentation.

The broken docstring is in octavia_lib/api/drivers/provider_base.py. Fix
that docstring and build apidocs - like octavia does - so that all
docstrings in this repo get tested.

For building apidocs, add the needed configuration to the sphinx files
and require the package.

Change-Id: Iad03f19083d9a5429dcfed3499d1c3e2d56cbb0f
Co-Authored-By: Jeremy Stanley <fungi@yuggoth.org>
Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2019-06-28 07:27:59.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid parallel discover_hosts (nova-related race condition)

In a rare event both kolla-ansible and nova-scheduler try to do
the mapping at the same time and one of them fails.
Since kolla-ansible runs host discovery on each deployment,
there is no need to change the default of no periodic host discovery.

commit_message:
Avoid parallel discover_hosts (nova-related race condition)

In a rare event both kolla-ansible and nova-scheduler try to do
the mapping at the same time and one of them fails.
Since kolla-ansible runs host discovery on each deployment,
there is no need to change the default of no periodic host discovery.

I added some notes for future. They are not critical.
I made the decision explicit in the comments.
I changed the task name to satisfy recommendations.
I removed the variable because it is not used (to avoid future doubts).

Closes-Bug: #1832987
Change-Id: I3128472f028a2dbd7ace02abc179a9629ad74ceb
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit ce680bcfe2208f19a23630ee3feff4b9bd40c595)
(cherry picked from commit ed3d1e37ffa3c513957e184693d5ae7e451e92d8)

commit_message:
Baremetal provisioning in UEFI secure boot mode for iLO drivers

This commit implements baremetal provisioning in UEFI secure boot
environment for iLO drivers when flavor requests node with
capabilities 'secure_deploy:True' and signed deploy ramdisk is used
for deploy.

Partial-bug: #1526755
Change-Id: I1fe60ae235b920071023c65f24dea48f5e3b5c6c

Thank you Dmitry, have posted reply to your comment.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2016-04-21 15:51:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

Understanding IPA, iLO, and virtual media modes, this seems redundant because the  driver can already enforce the default boot mode for the hardware, which as I understand it, means that the hardware has to be booted via a compatible method or it won't boot at all.

Anything beyond a capability in that case seems superfluous as the remaining is all environmental configuration constraints in terms of IPA images and how the nodes are configured to boot."}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2016-04-25 11:28:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Thank you Julia for the review.

This is about a special case wherein operator wants to perform deployment in UEFI secure boot environment. It can be done using new capability (say 'secure_deploy_mode') instead of configuration variable. The reason for introducing configuration variable is:-
1. For the deployment to happen in UEFI secure boot mode, node should be in UEFI boot mode. If node is in Legacy BIOS mode, deployment would fail as changing the boot mode to UEFI and enabling secure boot is a two step process needing two server reboot.
Even if operator were to keep servers in UEFI boot mode where he enables capability 'secure_deploy_mode', any instance request with boot_mode capability of 'bios' can change the boot mode on the node. This would cause the failure in the future deployment with capability 'secure_deploy_mode' being set to True.
2. Config variable helps in preventing such silent change in setup of the nodes as it is possible to prevent any deploy in legacy bios mode whenever this config parameter is enabled.

However, I do agree with you and Dmitry that enabling a feature through Config parameter is not right way.
Would it be fine to enable this through 'capabilities' and document this side effect? WDYT?"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2016-04-26 15:03:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Would it be fine to enable this through 'capabilities' and document this side effect? WDYT?

+1, works for me"}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2016-04-27 04:40:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

Thanks Shivanand. LGTM.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2016-04-28 15:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@Shivanand, With your reply, I still don’t see a case for adding a new parameter helps the situation since we already have capabilities settings for secure_boot = true and boot_mode="uefi"
 which as I understand, once it is set and enforced upon the iLO, all future boots leverage that setting.

I guess my confusion with this is that, as I understand it based on discussions with the team, once secure_boot is set for a chassis, bios boot mode can never be explicitly requested and the iLO has to be manually switched back to BIOS mode.  I don’t see how adding an additional configuration variable setting actually helps guard against a potential failure when the driver should be have enough information available to begin with, and either assert/correct the environment or error appropriately.'}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2016-04-28 17:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@Julia, secure_boot=True is a capability that turns on secure boot on BM for the instance if it is being requested. When the node is teared down, it is turned off. The BM can be subsequently used to create instance with legacy BIOS boot mode. There is no manual changing of boot mode required.
However, if the BM was used for deploying secure boot and a subsequent request for legacy BIOS, then deploy operation would happen in UEFI boot mode and when node goes for a second reboot when deploy is complete (instance becoming active), it would boot in the legacy BIOS boot mode.

This feature is to extend the UEFI secure boot in deploy process using signed ramdisk.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2016-04-29 13:52:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Shivanand and I discussed this yesterday and there is a partial misunderstanding rooted in a driver deficiency.  I still think we should strongly push users towards an all or nothing approach given the nature of dual boot images, but Shivanand is going to revise the specification, and see what can be done regarding the driver deficiency that my understanding is based upon.'}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2016-05-04 05:49:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-05-04 05:54:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2016-07-25 18:07:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This seems like it should be a setting on the Node (eg, always use UEFI secure boot with this node, including deploy phase, cleaning phase, rescue phase, etc) rather than a property of the Nova Flavor.

Since the secure_boot mode is already exposed in the nova flavor, I don't understand what benefit there is from adding a second flag (secure_deploy) to the nova flavor as well."}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2016-07-26 04:38:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)

Thank you Jim and Devananda for the review. Please see my replies inline.'}, {'account_id': 22255, 'date': '2017-03-22 04:48:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22255, 'date': '2017-03-22 04:48:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-03-22 04:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified-1

commit_message:
Baremetal provisioning in UEFI secure boot mode

This spec proposes mechanism to provision a node in UEFI secure
boot environment when flavor requests node with capabilities
'secure_boot:True' and signed deploy ramdisk is used for deploy.

Partial-Bug: 1526755
Change-Id: Ic6c5db9ceab43c4fd70b41bc12ac21b3f09a9762

(18 comments)

I am a bit lost. I don't really understand the scope of the problem and I don't want to try to guess. The API confused me even more."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2015-10-26 05:11:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

To be honest, I didn't read to the end, as I have questions to the problem and the solution. I see two specs here:

1. Extending tags with support for group operations. Sounds reasonable and doable.

2. Some kind of native (?) group management. I understand it as a tag/group related to some grouping entity in a vendor-specific hardware manager. This is much harder, as it might require linking a tag to a driver + some properties.

I'd like us to start with first, as spec on tags is already landed, and tags look like a good way of grouping nodes. I'd like us to discuss idea #2 on the summit, if possible. Please start with splitting this spec, if you don't mind."}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2015-10-26 05:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2015-10-26 05:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(18 comments)

Thank you Ruby for the review. Have addressed your comments as part of patchs set 3. Please have a look.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-26 05:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-ironic-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/44/235344/3/check/gate-ironic-specs-docs/a2831ce//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 29s
- gate-ironic-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/44/235344/3/check/gate-ironic-specs-python27/d47cc05/ : SUCCESS in 2m 28s'}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2015-10-27 17:35:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

With this change there will be tags, chassis and groups in ironic, and their meanings seem a bit overlapping to me.'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2015-10-28 01:26:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Guess I'll wait til the design session because I don't understand this."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2015-10-28 02:37:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

The "alternative" mentioned here, node tagging, has already been approved and therefor supercedes this work.

Furthermore, there are logical contradictions within the (addmitedly massive) architectural changes that would be needed to accomodate such groupings. How can it be reasonable to apply some arbitrary change to a filtered subset of a group, when the group API makes assumptions that all members of group have a unified target state?

Lastly, this spec does not describe at all the (again, massive) changes in the conductor manager that would be necessary to support something like this. 

I do not see how this proposal adds value to warrant the complexity and effort, over and above what the competing "taggin" work has proposed.'}, {'account_id': 8106, 'date': '2015-10-28 06:49:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Thanks Shivanand for the proposal.

I think this is good idea, bug we have same 'tagging' bp already.

IMO, think 'tagging' function can cover all logic group function, so there will be big overlap with 'tag' and 'group' bp, so can we just fill the gap which 'tag' bp still not supporting, bug 'group' bp can support, any more ideas?

And left some concern inline."}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2015-11-02 10:47:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2015-12-17 11:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2016-01-06 20:56:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi,

We recently reorganized the ironic-specs repository and now have a specs/not-implemented directory. After rebasing, please add a soft link there (via 'ln -s ../approved/<your-file>', 'git add <your-file>') so that your spec will show up at http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/#approved-specifications. Sorry for the inconvenience."}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2016-04-19 10:45:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2016-04-19 10:45:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-04-19 18:04:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

commit_message:
Group management of Ironic nodes

This spec proposes grouping of Ironic nodes to perform group
management operations using proposed CLI and REST APIs.

Partial-Bug: 1526487

Change-Id: I8d0d8dad3fd1be07ac1a137e77cb00e20cb1e97e

It's just a library we consume, there is no reason to use its
git head. Currently 1.4.0 is breaking us.

The stable version of this patch was reworked to cover legacy jobs.

Story: #2006301
Task: #36014
Change-Id: Ib1b1e32bc60d7ec271098dcd17086f79518c09df
(cherry picked from commit 3dfce5f2de6377d74632bb2a7fe3d382ccc629b0)
"}]
commit_message:
CI: stop using pyghmi from git master

It's just a library we consume, there is no reason to use its
git head. Currently 1.4.0 is breaking us.

The stable version of this patch was reworked to cover legacy jobs.

Story: #2006301
Task: #36014
Change-Id: Ib1b1e32bc60d7ec271098dcd17086f79518c09df
(cherry picked from commit 3dfce5f2de6377d74632bb2a7fe3d382ccc629b0)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-23 13:27:10.000000000', 'message': 'Set irrelevant files on CI jobs

All jobs are triggered regardless of files changed, except for files
already defined in octavia-dsvm-base. This means many jobs that not
impacted by a given change will be run in CI. Not only this is a waste
of resources but the job may also fail (e.g. timeouts) and block changes
from merging.

This patch defines a more granular set of irrelevant files per job. For
example, it prevents active-standby jobs from running when a change is
limited to normal scenario files.

Change-Id: I9eba013fb0b87afc44187e259b594f9b93bcc5d9
'}, {'created': '2019-06-23 14:39:38.000000000', 'message': 'Set irrelevant files on CI jobs

All jobs are triggered regardless of files changed, except for files
already defined in octavia-dsvm-base. This means many jobs that are not
impacted by a given change will be run in CI. Not only this is a waste
of CI resources but undeeded jobs may also fail (e.g. timeouts), thus
blocking changes from merging.

This patch defines a more granular set of irrelevant files per job. For
example, it prevents active-standby jobs from running when a change is
limited to normal scenario files.

Change-Id: I9eba013fb0b87afc44187e259b594f9b93bcc5d9
'}, {'created': '2019-07-01 18:24:55.000000000', 'message': 'Set irrelevant files on CI jobs

All jobs are triggered regardless of files changed, except for files
already defined in octavia-dsvm-base. This means many jobs that are not
impacted by a given change will be run in CI. Not only this is a waste
of CI resources but undeeded jobs may also fail (e.g. timeouts), thus
blocking changes from merging.

This patch defines a more granular set of irrelevant files per job. For
example, it prevents active-standby jobs from running when a change is
limited to normal scenario files.

Change-Id: I9eba013fb0b87afc44187e259b594f9b93bcc5d9
'}]
commit_message:
Set irrelevant files on CI jobs

All jobs are triggered regardless of files changed, except for files
already defined in octavia-dsvm-base. This means many jobs that are not
impacted by a given change will be run in CI. Not only this is a waste
of CI resources but undeeded jobs may also fail (e.g. timeouts), thus
blocking changes from merging.

This patch defines a more granular set of irrelevant files per job. For
example, it prevents active-standby jobs from running when a change is
limited to normal scenario files.

Change-Id: I9eba013fb0b87afc44187e259b594f9b93bcc5d9

subject: Remove the release notes job from stable/rocky
messages: [{'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-07-02 15:29:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-07-22 20:28:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-08-03 00:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-02 15:29:21.000000000', 'message': 'Remove the release notes job from stable/rocky

The release notes tools require the master branch to have the
full release notes configuration. Since neutron-lbaas has been retired
these no longer exist.
Because of this, the docs team recommends removing the release notes
jobs from the stable branches[1].

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-doc/ \
    %23openstack-doc.2019-07-02.log.html#t2019-07-02T05:58:56

Change-Id: I813574625f6e3cf89e193ce850dec319a5b605ff
'}]
commit_message:
Remove the release notes job from stable/rocky

The release notes tools require the master branch to have the
full release notes configuration. Since neutron-lbaas has been retired
these no longer exist.
Because of this, the docs team recommends removing the release notes
jobs from the stable branches[1].

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-doc/ \
    %23openstack-doc.2019-07-02.log.html#t2019-07-02T05:58:56

Change-Id: I813574625f6e3cf89e193ce850dec319a5b605ff

commit_message:
Update tox.ini for new upper constraints strategy

The requirements team has defined a new strategy for handling
upper constraints[1]. This patch applies those strategies to
neutron-lbaas.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/ \
    2019-May/006478.html

Change-Id: I7731864366b8271cb698f8f68fdd650b074a28ff

commit_message:
Remove the release notes job from stable/queens

The release notes tools require the master branch to have the
full release notes configuration. Since neutron-lbaas has been retired
these no longer exist.
Because of this, the docs team recommends removing the release notes
jobs from the stable branches[1].

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-doc/ \
    %23openstack-doc.2019-07-02.log.html#t2019-07-02T05:58:56

Change-Id: I655a9bb5797bea103d36f104042d3e1c70b4a706

commit_message:
Support for testing adoption in the standalone job

This change adds a test for adoption. It's off by default because
it's destructive (removes and re-adds a node) and requires reading
(or guessing) the BMC credentials.

Change-Id: I0178c2b906449802ce38059d4191a63b4b317226

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-29 14:01:22.000000000', 'message': "IPA does not boot up after cleaning reboot for 'redfish' bios interface

The clean steps of 'redfish' bios interface does not set up deploy ramdisk
before initiating the cleaning reboot of bare metal.

Change-Id: I979358ead1e19f9b24f23117d0cba3479e33707b
Story: 2006217

commit_message:
IPA does not boot up after cleaning reboot for 'redfish' bios interface

The clean steps of 'redfish' bios interface does not set up deploy ramdisk
before initiating the cleaning reboot of bare metal.

Change-Id: I979358ead1e19f9b24f23117d0cba3479e33707b
Story: 2006217
Task: 35810
(cherry picked from commit ddc0fb831b80ac60446cc47c7ec4e1d0848411b5)

commit_message:
CI: clean up the required projects list for grenade

We don't need to install libraries from git in this job.
ironic-python-agent is also not needed since we download the ramdisk.

Change-Id: I634e75ab04253edffb6f19394d3943e9ffe56d13
(cherry picked from commit da69fca0f8c32880604be14100598a1e1da4c7f2)

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

Change-Id: I7410ad173a84b30562a1cdad743553dbd432f729

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-02 17:49:11.000000000', 'message': 'Fix broken metadata_settings for redis templates

metadata_settings in docker/services/redis.yaml was returning a list
of two items rather than one as expected. As a result, the compact/
mangedby service principals were not being created by novajoin service.
This results ina permission issue during overcloud deploy as the
`getcert` request will hit a permissions issue during Step2.

Note that this only affects Rocky and earlier branches. The issue was
resolved in Stein when redis service was flattened[1,2].

- Push tls logic into redis-base and consume in child templates.
- Move away from use_tls_proxy to more accurate internal_tls_enabled
- Ensure redis service has both service principals created if internal
  tls is enabled
[1] - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635930/
[2] - https://review.opendev.org/640944

Change-Id: Ic781905b63a0635b7bd0c7079fa84ca1e7f93989
Partial-bug: #1838679
(cherry picked from commit b96b049f983662ea0badbca5d4f7b0e95b880338)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix broken metadata_settings for redis templates

metadata_settings in docker/services/redis.yaml was returning a list
of two items rather than one as expected. As a result, the compact/
mangedby service principals were not being created by novajoin service.
This results ina permission issue during overcloud deploy as the
`getcert` request will hit a permissions issue during Step2.

Note that this only affects Rocky and earlier branches. The issue was
resolved in Stein when redis service was flattened[1,2].

- Push tls logic into redis-base and consume in child templates.
- Move away from use_tls_proxy to more accurate internal_tls_enabled
- Ensure redis service has both service principals created if internal
  tls is enabled
[1] - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635930/
[2] - https://review.opendev.org/640944

Change-Id: Ic781905b63a0635b7bd0c7079fa84ca1e7f93989
Partial-bug: #1838679
(cherry picked from commit b96b049f983662ea0badbca5d4f7b0e95b880338)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-17 15:46:53.000000000', 'message': 'Make nova ephemeral storage backend configurable per-role

When multiple Compute roles are used, admins may want to use different storage
backends on each role.

This change turns NovaEnableRbdBackend into a role specific param.
Any other config that is implicitly enabled by the global NovaEnableRbdBackend
now requires a dedicated param.

Co-Authored-By: ratailor@redhat.com
Change-Id: I9f40a2a3561fcb1d1fec9d9c3c1f9cabaf02650c

commit_message:
Make nova ephemeral storage backend configurable per-role

When multiple Compute roles are used, admins may want to use different storage
backends on each role.

This change turns NovaEnableRbdBackend into a role specific param.
Any other config that is implicitly enabled by the global NovaEnableRbdBackend
now requires a dedicated param.

Co-Authored-By: ratailor@redhat.com
Change-Id: I9f40a2a3561fcb1d1fec9d9c3c1f9cabaf02650c
Implements: blueprint nova-backend-per-role
(cherry picked from commit 65d7e55f549875636d314fff09707ca2650084a0)
(cherry picked from commit ed8d9da9b688a17d9a2c7cddf9a53722a8d359bf)
(cherry picked from commit b1febf785df9f7dfadd05637b622fb6568f52003)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 11090, 'name': 'Sergii Golovatiuk', 'email': 'sgolovat@redhat.com', 'username': 'holser'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 20172, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@acksyn.org', 'username': 'michele'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages: [{'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2019-08-01 14:43:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-08-01 16:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-08-02 07:04:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-08-02 13:24:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2019-08-02 22:09:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit e2c5deba1d1fce3c9001364f51aa09565223aee3'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-01 14:43:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix swift-proxy healthcheck

With the current swift-proxy healthcheck the container status is
unhealty even the service is up.

The used ps/grep won't return the swift proxy processes as the
output gets truncated:

()[root@overcloud-controller-0 /]$ ps -e
    PID TTY          TIME CMD
      1 ?        00:00:00 dumb-init
      6 ?        00:02:52 swift-proxy-ser
     28 ?        00:00:25 swift-proxy-ser
   4753 pts/1    00:00:00 sh
   4797 pts/1    00:00:00 ps

As a result we end up in the else, checking the cache.

This moves the if to use pgrep instead.

Change-Id: I169b07553b171fcacb532bf58acc4200e270bfbb
"}]
commit_message:
Fix swift-proxy healthcheck

With the current swift-proxy healthcheck the container status is
unhealty even the service is up.

The used ps/grep won't return the swift proxy processes as the
output gets truncated:

()[root@overcloud-controller-0 /]$ ps -e
    PID TTY          TIME CMD
      1 ?        00:00:00 dumb-init
      6 ?        00:02:52 swift-proxy-ser
     28 ?        00:00:25 swift-proxy-ser
   4753 pts/1    00:00:00 sh
   4797 pts/1    00:00:00 ps

As a result we end up in the else, checking the cache.

This moves the if to use pgrep instead.

Change-Id: I169b07553b171fcacb532bf58acc4200e270bfbb

commit_message:
Action #Bios.ResetBios fails as POST request has no body

Bios action #Bios.ResetBios fails with HTTP code 415 as BMC expects
the POST request with empty body instead of no body.

Change-Id: I8d234b3e562a46d3be27f6eae83b6f2e99813c83
Story: 2006246
Task: 35854

commit_message:
Add var to override hash used for repo setup

The image build playbook, when used for periodic, requires
a different hash to set up repos. This review adds the
var to enable the override.

Change-Id: Ia18962abb58954169a86a0833fee33fcbde81601

commit_message:
Ensure that systemd directory exists during series upgrade

When upgrading from trusty to xenial, the charm switches to systemd.
However, the directory /etc/systemd/system/ceilometer-api.service.d
doesn't exist as the charm installed on trusty.  This change ensures
that the directory does exist during series upgrade.

Change-Id: Icc3617f97b0a28c5a3779b60bde90144d661697a
Closes-Bug: #1838634

It's probably weird that StreamingPile has this interfaces that swallows
exceptions, but this seems better than hanging.

commit_message:
service_setup: refactor service setup to a single file

This patch refactors the openstack user/service/endpoints creation to
service_setup.yml which will eventually be managed by

messages: [{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-08-01 11:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-02 12:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-02 19:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-01 11:09:57.000000000', 'message': 'Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Also heat_init_systemd is finally dropped, as it is not used anymore.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I321979a96acc04a25b5287fb2f61fa03cda66e81
'}]
commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Also heat_init_systemd is finally dropped, as it is not used anymore.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I321979a96acc04a25b5287fb2f61fa03cda66e81

During original patch ability to override region was missing. This patch
return functionality of defining region during keystone service creation

It also updates a bit service_setup with ability to provide domain.

commit_message:
Generate addition drop-in dependencies for podman containers

If a container managed by Paunch and has the drop-in file enabled, we
want to start the containers with the script provided by the Paunch rpm:
paunch-start-podman-container

The script will take care of proper ordering when creating systemd scope
files.

Partial-Bug: #1838668
Change-Id: Idaf5d4871ad1231f2592238a7925857af8f40548
(cherry picked from commit b33aeea9728233aca852a3e132f23fca71ac42df)

commit_message:
Make nova ephemeral storage backend configurable per-role

When multiple Compute roles are used, admins may want to use different storage
backends on each role.

This change turns NovaEnableRbdBackend into a role specific param.
Any other config that is implicitly enabled by the global NovaEnableRbdBackend
now requires a dedicated param.

Co-Authored-By: ratailor@redhat.com
Change-Id: I9f40a2a3561fcb1d1fec9d9c3c1f9cabaf02650c
Implements: blueprint nova-backend-per-role
(cherry picked from commit 65d7e55f549875636d314fff09707ca2650084a0)
(cherry picked from commit ed8d9da9b688a17d9a2c7cddf9a53722a8d359bf)

commit_message:
Pin rspec-puppet-facts if older ruby

1.9.5 version of rspec-puppet-facts requires a newer ruby. Since we
still test with centos7 (which has older ruby), we need to add a
conditional to pull in the correct rspec-puppet-facts version

Change-Id: I357f7b86dda6d6813f39dd6d276b94aeee87af12

correctly when user customizes the CephFS pool name.

'_cleanup_incomplete_backup_operations' method is called

commit_message:
Fix ceph driver error during incremental backup creation

During the incremental backups creation, unexpectedly the
'_cleanup_incomplete_backup_operations' method is called
aborting the backup.

This happens when using ceph mimic with Python 3.x.
The connections with Librbd suddenly abort connections
before accessing the data.

The fix is to extend the connection and close it at the
end of the method.

Change-Id: I6b854745462af993fe143ca9cacbf863fb80686e
Closes-Bug: #1838691

commit_message:
Revert "Blacklist bandit 1.6.0"

This reverts commit ebac8330d8ac81c491a1cb0e16eb23b93d7932ee.

Using the glob that I had not yet had enough coffee to do correctly is a
better solution, and allows us to fix new failures in 1.6.0 which would
break us again when 1.6.1 was released.

Change-Id: Ica473ba71b224cdc0acf815f82d534b6c70a7f54
(cherry picked from commit dc3175afb16fedaf5216b5d4a7a521d16636b4d1)

recheck'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-07-17 13:37:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-07-17 15:07:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

Can you post an example of how this would be used (maybe as a review in the heat-templates repo)?

My big concern is that this requires the ID of both the autoscaling group and the stack that contains the loadbalancer member. There seems to be one of these alarms for each loadbalancer member? So the logical way would be to have this resource in the scaled unit, and use {get_param: OS::stack_id} as the stack ID. However, in that scenario I can't think of a way to get the ID of the autoscaling group. So it's not clear to me that it's possible to use this resource in practice."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-07-29 02:18:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Can you post an example of how this would be used (maybe as a
 > review in the heat-templates repo)?

Hi Zane, you can find a brief description here[1].

 > 
 > My big concern is that this requires the ID of both the autoscaling
 > group and the stack that contains the loadbalancer member. There
 > seems to be one of these alarms for each loadbalancer member? 

Not for each lb member, but for each lb pool which is actually the autoscaling group.

This Alarm is specific for the scenario described in [1], tightly integrated with Heat and Octavia. This scenario brings much value to the end-users(at least for the users of our own public cloud) who are using Heat for the application orchestration. There is no convenient way to do the same thing currently.

[1]: https://docs.openstack.org/self-healing-sig/latest/use-cases/loadbalancer-member.html'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-07-29 14:35:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

> > Can you post an example of how this would be used (maybe as a
> > review in the heat-templates repo)?

> Hi Zane, you can find a brief description here[1].

Yeah, I'm familiar with that, but I'd like to see an actual template to prove that it can actually be used in Heat in a practical sense, since when you set it up manually you may be relying on information that is easily obtainable after the fact from the command line but not necessarily from the point in the tree of stacks where this resource needs to be created.

> > My big concern is that this requires the ID of both the autoscaling
> > group and the stack that contains the loadbalancer member. There
> > seems to be one of these alarms for each loadbalancer member? 

> Not for each lb member, but for each lb pool which is actually the autoscaling group.

Ah, OK, that's fine then.

So you would have a top-level template that contains the scaling group, the loadbalancer pool, and this alarm. And you would pass {get_param: OS::stack_id} for the `stack` and {get_resource: autoscaling_group} for the `autoscaling_group_id`?

I think we need to update the help strings to correctly describe which stack ID the user should pass and what it's used for. I personally would have been unable to correctly use this resource from the description given, and I know a *lot* more about how autohealing works in Heat than practically any user.

Please also add a release note.

Other than that, the patch looks OK."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-07-30 00:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Thanks Zane, I believe Simon already got an example template used for testing.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2019-07-30 02:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

For testing purposes I have been using the following in my heat template to create the LBMemberHealthAlarm

  loadbalancer_member_health_alarm:
    type: OS::Aodh::LBMemberHealthAlarm
    properties:
      description: Foo bar baz
      alarm_actions: []
      repeat_actions: false
      pool: {get_resource: loadbalancer_pool}
      stack: {get_param: "OS::stack_id"}
      autoscaling_group_id: {get_resource: autoscaling_group}

https://github.com/iokiwi/heat-templates/blob/master/autoscaling-autohealing/webserver_stack.yaml'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2019-08-02 00:40:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2019-08-02 00:41:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-02 13:46:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

commit_message:
Add heat resource for creating Aodh loadbalancer_member_health alarm type[1]

Aodh loadbalancer_member_health alarm was implemented in 654221[2]. This patch
adds a corresponding heat resource for managing it's lifecycle.

 - Add new resource OS:Aodh:LBMemberHealthAlarm
 - Add unit test for LoadBalancerMemberHealthAlarms

[1]: https://docs.openstack.org/aodh/latest/contributor/architecture.html#id5
[2]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654221/

Change-Id: I26582fbd0b980d848f7e4cdb8bb2c8833385fe9b
Task: 34767

commit_message:
WIP: Add enhancement to mariadb backup

  * Enabling swift remote capability to the backup script
  * Enabling swift remote capability to the restore script
  * Add test job for remote backup
  * Add test job for pvc backup

Depend-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672738
Change-Id: Idffaefb350f380a86d0ae5fa854fc31b3659bf2e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-01 18:46:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix broken metadata_settings for redis templates

metadata_settings in docker/services/redis.yaml was returning a list
of two items rather than one as expected. As a result, the compact/
mangedby service principals were not being created by novajoin service.
This results ina permission issue during overcloud deploy as the
`getcert` request will hit a permissions issue during Step2.

- Push tls logic into redis-base and consume in child templates.
- Move away from use_tls_proxy to more accurate internal_tls_enabled
- Ensure redis service has both service principals created if internal
  tls is enabled

Change-Id: Ic781905b63a0635b7bd0c7079fa84ca1e7f93989
Partial-bug: #1838679
'}, {'created': '2019-08-01 19:11:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix broken metadata_settings for redis templates

metadata_settings in docker/services/redis.yaml was returning a list
of two items rather than one as expected. As a result, the compact/
mangedby service principals were not being created by novajoin service.
This results ina permission issue during overcloud deploy as the
`getcert` request will hit a permissions issue during Step2.

Note that this only affects Rocky and earlier branches. The issue was
resolved in Stein when redis service was flattened[1,2].

- Push tls logic into redis-base and consume in child templates.
- Move away from use_tls_proxy to more accurate internal_tls_enabled
- Ensure redis service has both service principals created if internal
  tls is enabled
[1] - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635930/
[2] - https://review.opendev.org/640944

Change-Id: Ic781905b63a0635b7bd0c7079fa84ca1e7f93989
Partial-bug: #1838679
'}]
commit_message:
Fix broken metadata_settings for redis templates

metadata_settings in docker/services/redis.yaml was returning a list
of two items rather than one as expected. As a result, the compact/
mangedby service principals were not being created by novajoin service.
This results ina permission issue during overcloud deploy as the
`getcert` request will hit a permissions issue during Step2.

Note that this only affects Rocky and earlier branches. The issue was
resolved in Stein when redis service was flattened[1,2].

- Push tls logic into redis-base and consume in child templates.
- Move away from use_tls_proxy to more accurate internal_tls_enabled
- Ensure redis service has both service principals created if internal
  tls is enabled
[1] - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635930/
[2] - https://review.opendev.org/640944

Change-Id: Ic781905b63a0635b7bd0c7079fa84ca1e7f93989
Partial-bug: #1838679

subject: Use expanding bindparam in provider_ids_from_rp_ids in_
messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-01 14:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:02:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Need to bump required sqlalchemy version of the expanding kwarg.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:26:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:30:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

lgtm, just waiting on CI results. I can't really speak much to the actual change itself, the docs on this are a bit confusing to me, but it was recommended by zzzeek himself so I'll trust in that.

I know that baked queries was also mentioned in IRC and it sounds like maybe this will replace that (?), and I've seen some changes to neutron - or neutron plugins - that fixed some major performance issues with using baked queries (I only saw those changes b/c they were proposed as stable backports), but anyway it sounds like we should be doing this (and nova would probably gain from this stuff as well but no one is doing that type of auditing unfortunately)."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:36:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I know that baked queries was also mentioned in IRC and it sounds
 > like maybe this will replace that (?), and I've seen some changes
 > to neutron - or neutron plugins - that fixed some major performance
 > issues with using baked queries (I only saw those changes b/c they
 > were proposed as stable backports), but anyway it sounds like we
 > should be doing this (and nova would probably gain from this stuff
 > as well but no one is doing that type of auditing unfortunately).

We talked about baked queries in IRC, and apparently they really only come into play when using ORM features, which placement uses only rarely (and not in the queries changed here)."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-01 21:48:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-02 13:25:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-02 14:30:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-02 15:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

This is identical to PS3 where Matt was +2, so fast approving.'}]

This was explored as part of discussion with zzzeek on various
ways to make a statement with a large in_ be more performant.

Batching the queries by chunking rp_ids did not help, but an
expanding bindparam did: it makes the surrounding method about
50% faster [1].

[1] With the caveat that profiling and benchmarking are very
different things, and in this case it is profiling results
which are being analysed.

commit_message:
Use expanding bindparam in provider_ids_from_rp_ids in_

This was explored as part of discussion with zzzeek on various
ways to make a statement with a large in_ be more performant.

Batching the queries by chunking rp_ids did not help, but an
expanding bindparam did: it makes the surrounding method about
50% faster [1].

bindparam expanding was added in sqlalchemy 1.2.0 so we bump
the requirements here to the latest 1.2.x bugfix release,
1.2.19.

[1] With the caveat that profiling and benchmarking are very
different things, and in this case it is profiling results
which are being analysed.

Change-Id: Ic4e0cdd87f8f2d76b921059ac4bf16a838913abf

subject: Use __slots__ in commonly used objects
messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-02 09:29:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-02 09:36:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-02 13:33:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

This looks OK to me. __slots__ is something I heard about when I heard Heat improved performance quite a bit by using it awhile back. I've often wondered if nova could benefit - I'm sure it could, at least for things like the HostState object in the scheduler which wraps a ComputeNode versioned object. I'm less sure about whether or not slots would help versioned objects since they internalize their fields and such, but anyway I'm just musing. Cool if this makes things faster since it's simple."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-02 13:34:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Random question but do you have a blog post or anything about how you are comparing CPU cost before and after this change for profiling? I know you have posted a few blogs about performance and scale testing. Unfortunately I don't know if those would translate to doing similar kind of profiling on something like the nova-scheduler if I changed HostState to use slots."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-02 14:18:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-02 14:42:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Random question but do you have a blog post or anything about how
 > you are comparing CPU cost before and after this change for
 > profiling? I know you have posted a few blogs about performance and
 > scale testing. Unfortunately I don't know if those would translate
 > to doing similar kind of profiling on something like the
 > nova-scheduler if I changed HostState to use slots.

If the area of inspection was HostState, then I think what we'd probably need to do is instrument the host manager to listen a signal, when it heard that signal it would start profiling itself (using cProfile [1] ). When it heard the signal again, it would stop. That is, there needs to be some way to not be overwhelmed by data. The stuff in placement does it per web request, dumping the prof data to a file identified by a timestamp and the URL.

What I use to compare cpu usage is navigating around in the prof with snakeviz [2] and simply comparing numbers and vague things like "the size of the circles".

Whereas osprofiler would allow you to see how much time is spent in particulal interactions which have been previously labelled by osprofiler as traceable, using cProfiler counts up and times every python function or method call, which can lead you to a particular method that seems more expensive than it should (for example provider_ids_from_rp_ids).

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/profile.html
[2] https://pypi.org/project/snakeviz/'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-02 15:25:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(4 comments)

This is the same as PS1 where Matt was +2. Fast approving.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-02 15:30:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Based on reviewing some of the recent test data it's looking like this change is going to have the single largest impact, but with the addition of the summaries_by_id cache, that impact will be less visible once everything is merged."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-02 15:43:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-02 16:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}]

so we won't do this wholesale.

A unit test is updated to change a mock from a public ResourceProvider

commit_message:
Use __slots__ in commonly used objects

When making a nested provider GET /allocation_candidates request
that returns around 6500 providers in the providers summary section,
we make ~22000 ResourceProvider and ProviderSummary objects, 7500
AllocationRequest objects and 30000 ProviderSummaryResource objects.

In aggregate, creating and accessing these objects contributes a
measurable cpu time cost. Using __slots__ [1] can speed up attribute
access (I measured it, it does), so lets use it for the common
objects. There's no evidence (yet) of other objects being an issue
so we won't do this wholesale.

A unit test is updated to change a mock from a public ResourceProvider
method (set_aggregates) to a private function (_set_aggregates)
because one of the limitations of __slots__ is it makes the
slotted objects difficult to mock. In this case the test is still
testing the same thing.

Subsequent patches will explore why we need 22000 ProviderSummary
objects when we're only producing 6500 resulting summaries to see
if there is a cleanup that can be done there.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#slots

Change-Id: I4acb16d13976d64d47f798ebbec626a73b79b4f5

commit_message:
Force the kill of the "nc" process only if timeout

If the file is received correctly, the "nc" process in the remote
machine will end gracefully. Only in case of socket timeout, will force
the completion of the process before returning.

Change-Id: I6cec868daa0139f6a49807883f901d2eac84fe14
Related-Bug: #1838068

commit_message:
Implement class to configure parameters to use service token

This patch introduces nova::keystone::service_user class
to configure parameters to enable service token feature
in Nova.

commit_message:
Make gerritbot notify #openstack-neutron IRC channel of stable reviews

Currently the openstackgerrit gerritbot is only notifying the
#openstack-neutron IRC channel of reviews submitted to master.
So add notifications for stable branches, as per this discussion:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-neutron/%23openstack-neutron.2019-08-02.log.html#t2019-08-02T08:47:29

Change-Id: I716ab52ea7d6f5676d6cef5f2067cfdb495f8dc4

commit_message:
ceph-nfs: Add rpcbind to Ubuntu host bootstrap

* Ubuntu ships with nfs-ganesha 2.6.0, which requires to do an rpcbind
udp test on startup (was fixed later)
* Add rpcbind package to be installed by kolla-ansible bootstrap when
ceph_nfs is enabled
* Update Ceph deployment docs with a note

Change-Id: Ic19264191a0ed418fa959fdc122cef543446fbe5
(cherry picked from commit efcaf400b89d83db59871b97421d71d934b5b168)

commit_message:
Resolve puppet overwriting a pre-existing bootstrap-osd auth entry

Ceph jewel creates the client.bootstrap-osd auth entry when the cluster
is created. puppet-ceph has been overwriting this keyring in memory and
on the filesystem. This patch updates ceph::osd to exract the
client keyring from memory and write it to the filesystem. This will
means ceph::key will not need to create the client.bootstrap-osd keyring.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/667387/
Change-Id: I11f134bed59da706a03ce4a70d941145c16f8175
Partial-bug: 1769722
(cherry picked from commit d833c03b975c922a28281918a2ac71a3dd7a2104)

commit_message:
Add method 'all_required_traits' to scheduler utils

In order to set required CPU flags to libvirt, we have to first get all
required traits.

Change-Id: I6a10f55f777917d6caf2f09aa5b2ca7c4676b749
Implements: blueprint cpu-model-selection

Use static inventory YAML file for saving execution time

The validations execution will use now a static inventory file to speed
up things a bit. Note that this file will be removed after execution.

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4f55cdf59ad871dccf107e191c9c738c22fe26f4)

commit_message:
Don't use local connection by default for the validations

When using local connection, all the validations targeting the overcloud
nodes are failing. Let's use the connection mode from the Ansible
inventory.

Change-Id: I188604f7767b51a0f485bd79ff3497af56586b13
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 82887ef228659c7494f51b7e37eb177ff98b69bc)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-01 09:39:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add plan parameter to run_ansible_playbook function

This patch adds a new parameter called 'plan' (Defaults to "overcloud")
to the 'run_ansible_playbook' function. It will allow to execute
Validations with Ansible in a different plan or stack that the default
one through the TripleO CLI. Note That it was already possible only
while using Mistral but not for Ansible.

This patch also brings:
- Change the default values of the 'tags' and 'skip_tags' arguments
  to 'None' and fixes their non Pythonic tests.
- Add '--stack' alias to the '--plan' argument for 'validator run'
  command.

Change-Id: I6f8f55963f3f5261ec1497b650e0ca509d31dd32
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 17e56a01d5d1efbb9307addb80a92fe242595412)
'}]
commit_message:
Add plan parameter to run_ansible_playbook function

This patch adds a new parameter called 'plan' (Defaults to "overcloud")
to the 'run_ansible_playbook' function. It will allow to execute
Validations with Ansible in a different plan or stack that the default
one through the TripleO CLI. Note That it was already possible only
while using Mistral but not for Ansible.

This patch also brings:
- Change the default values of the 'tags' and 'skip_tags' arguments
  to 'None' and fixes their non Pythonic tests.
- Add '--stack' alias to the '--plan' argument for 'validator run'
  command.

Change-Id: I6f8f55963f3f5261ec1497b650e0ca509d31dd32
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 17e56a01d5d1efbb9307addb80a92fe242595412)
